territory.notes: An early 15th century Peul kingdom established in the floodplains of the Niger River within the area of Dia in present-day Mali. An overthrow of the ruling dynasty of the “Peul Kingdom of Macina” in 1810 led to the establishment of the “Peul Empire of Macina.” Prior to 1810, Macina appears to have been intermittently independent and subject to other kingdoms and empires, including as a vassal state to the Mali Empire in the 15th century, and also as a dependency of Moroccan and Songhay entities and even the Ségou Kingdom (after 1670). After the establishment of the Peul Empire of Macina in 1810, Macina remained independent until its demise. In 1862, shortly after conquering Ségou, El Hadj Omar Tall conquered Macina as well and incorporated it into his Tukulor Empire.
